ie

red to have my speeches in writing, w
c

r
L.
Other answear I had none more then they give c
o
monly
at
e first proposal of a matter. That they would take
advise upon it: w
c
yet they uttered unto me, w
t
signific
ao
n
of their griefe,
t
her H
es
would
ceede so directly against
her Treaty, and
t
in suche a season, as if their state were
throughly sifted, it would be found in greater danger then
it was at
e time of
e making of
e C
o
tract. They have
mette very often about
e matter, and yesterday after noone,
because I
p
ssed them hard to know to w
at
effect I should
write to her M
ie
, the deputed one to tell me,
t
I must
needes have
e patience to attende a little longer, for that
they had not yet c
o
cluded w
at
answere they might make,
but founde it every way a matter full of infinit danger,
if they should not
ceede w
t
very great circumspection, for
w
c
they were agreed to imparte it out of hand to
Co. Maurice
and to
Co. William
and to
e
Councell of Estate
, w
c
are together
at
e Campe, to
e ende w
t
their advise they might determine
for
e best. As farre as I can c
o
jecture, they are fully
bent to satisfie her M
ie
in sending to
e
Provinces:
but I can
not yet
ceave in w
at
sorte they are inclyned, to propose
e matter to
e Provinces. For if they doe it effectually,
by imparting their advise, and by
suading w
t
e people to
assent to a certaine summe, either that w
c
I have signifyed,
or
t
they shall sette downe, I may happily have an
answear w
t
some expedition. But if they will not de-
termine to give direction to
e Provinces (as I finde them
t
way very backward) but shall barely make re

st to know

ies

jecture. I will
therfore endevor by all

m
heere before hande, to agree up
o

es
accept
ao
n
and to move
e generality to condescend thereunto. I have
publickly
posed, as her M
ie
willed, a hundred thousand po
u
[ds]
but they shew so little token of hearkening unto it, as I must
growe to other termes in my privat c
o
munic
ao
n, or els expec
t
to be denyed. For to informe you roundly w
at
I finde, wit
h
humble suite to yo
r
L. to make it knowen unto her M
ie
, I see
the
chiefest among them full of silence and sadnesse, for
e trouble
s
and disconfortes, w
c

o

of this c
o
trey, and to minister much matter of discouragem

ns, whereof a great c

ie,

ir

is noted of all men, of zele in Religion
of

o
trey, their excessive domages

at

o

they are very much in doubte of some soddaine alter

t
